img.altText: Picture of a woman in Saudi Arabia wearing a veil while watching over girls playing on a beach.
img.crdt: Photograph by Jodi Cobb, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: A story in the October 1987 issue examined the lives of women in Saudi Arabia. Here, a woman wears a traditional niqab, but the young girls won't start wearing the veil until they reach puberty.

caption.credit: Photograph by Jodi Cobb, Nat Geo Image Collection
caption.text: A story in the October 1987 issue examined the lives of women in Saudi Arabia. Here, a woman wears a traditional niqab, but the young girls won't start wearing the veil until they reach puberty.
caption.title: Saudi Women

img.altText: Picture of dolphins swimming through clear blue water in Hawaii
img.crdt: Photograph by Brian Skerry, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: Spinner dolphins return from foraging to a bay off Oahu, Hawaii. Spinner dolphins are highly social, gathering in groups that can number in the thousands.

img.altText: Picture of tourists standing in front of an elaborate rock carving near Tehran, Iran
img.crdt: Photograph by F. E. Murray, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: In this photo from the April 1921 issue, tourists stand in front of a 19th-century rock carving just south of Tehran, Iran. At the end of 2020, the tourism department of Tehran Province announced that the carving would undergo repair and preservation processes to combat years of damage and erosion.

caption.credit: Photograph by F. E. Murray, Nat Geo Image Collection
caption.text: In this photo from the April 1921 issue, tourists stand in front of a 19th-century rock carving just south of Tehran, Iran. img.altText: A beaver swims underwater in Grand Teton National Park
img.crdt: Photograph by Charlie Hamilton James, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: After being nearly eradicated by trappers in the mid-1800s, beavers are making a comeback in the West, including this river in Grand Teton National Park. To avoid predators, the large rodents can stay underwater for up to 15 minutes.

caption.credit: Photograph by Charlie Hamilton James, Nat Geo Image Collection
caption.text: After being nearly eradicated by trappers in the mid-1800s, beavers are making a comeback in the West, including this river in Grand Teton National Park. To avoid predators, the large rodents can stay underwater for up to 15 minutes.
caption.title: Busy Beaver

edgs.description: Citing rotten food, separating young cubs from their mothers, missing animals, and fraud, court cases aim to end the most exploitive practices.

img.altText: Picture of two tigers behind a cage
img.crdt: Photograph by Steve Winter, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: Wynnewood Oklahoma Tigers at Greater Wynnewood Exotic Animal Park made famous by Joe "Exotic" Schreibvogel. Now run by Jeff Lowe. This "park" has been famous as the #1 tiger BAD breeder in the US. You can see tigers and ligers and tiligers, crossing tigers and lions and lions and tigers. They have tiger cub petting, tiger cub selfies and interactions with other small animals. Jeff,(undercover) has 9 tigers on his property in Ringling Ok, that he saved from Joe Exotic and Jeff Lowe. He does cub petting of 3 cubs he "saved" to help pay for the food of the grown tigers.

edgs.abstract: Citing rotten food, separating young cubs from their mothers, missing animals, and fraud, court cases aim to end the most exploitive practices.
edgs.title: ‘Tiger King’ stars’ face scrutiny in court

edgs.description: Several decades after a groundbreaking album of whale "songs" first piqued public curiosity and started a global conservation movement, scientists continue to decode the wide array of vocalizations different whale species use to communicate.

img.dsc: New
img.ttl: Why a whale's world is a world of sound

edgs.abstract: Several decades after a groundbreaking album of whale "songs" first piqued public curiosity and started a global conservation movement, scientists continue to decode the wide array of vocalizations different whale species use to communicate.

edgs.description: Scientists struggle to explain why the gray whale population plummeted by nearly a quarter between 2016 and 2020.

img.altText: Picture of a whale blowing water with a rainbow above it
img.crdt: Photograph by Meghan Dhaliwal
img.dsc: February 6, 2021 - An adult grey whale swims in the calm waters just outside of the “Boca de Soledad,” the mouth where the Pacific ocean meets the series of bays known as the Bahía Magdalena. Grey whales migrate for six months a year—three months to travel down from their feeding grounds in Alaska to Baja Sur, Mexico, three months to calve in Baja Sur, three months to travel back north and three months of feeding in Alaska waters. Grey whales are baleen whales, meaning that they survive by eating tons of fat-rich microorganisms. Grey whales have been dying along their migration route at unexplainable rates (the NOAA is calling their deaths a UME, or an Unexplained Mortality Event) but scientists are beginning to theorize that warming seas are killing off the whale’s main food source in the north, leaving them malnourished on their migration. Image by Meghan Dhaliwal

edgs.abstract: Scientists struggle to explain why the gray whale population plummeted by nearly a quarter between 2016 and 2020.
edgs.title: Why are so many gray whales dying?

edgs.abstract: King Kong made the behavior famous, but scientists still know little about why the great apes perform this percussive display.
edgs.title: Why do male gorillas beat their chests? New study offers intriguing evidence

edgs.description: Personal protective equipment is made of plastic and isn't recyclable. Now it’s being found everywhere on earth, including the oceans. The solution isn’t complicated: Throw them away.

img.altText: a California sea lion encounters a discarded face mask
img.crdt: Photograph by Ralph Pace
img.dsc: The COVID - 19 pandemic’s effects extend to ocean ecosystems. Here, a California sea lion encounters a discarded face mask in the waters off Monterey.

edgs.abstract: Personal protective equipment is made of plastic and isn't recyclable. Now it’s being found everywhere on earth, including the oceans. The solution isn’t complicated: Throw them away.
edgs.title: How to stop discarded face masks from polluting the planet

edgs.description: Once found near present-day St. Louis in Illinois, Cahokia suddenly declined 600 years ago, and no one knows why.

img.crdt: Photograph by Ira Block, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: Cahokia's central plaza is now part of a 2,200-acre historical site.

edgs.abstract: Once found near present-day St. Louis in Illinois, Cahokia suddenly declined 600 years ago, and no one knows why.
edgs.title: Why was the ancient city of Cahokia abandoned? New clues rule out one theory.

img.dsc: Lightning flashes during a storm, Yukon, August.

edgs.abstract: Recent studies suggest lightning in the far North could double by 2100 and that the increase may already be underway.
edgs.title: Once-rare Arctic lightning is now more frequent—and may reshape the region

edgs.description: The tiny fishing fleet from St. Paul is losing the fight for halibut, up against factory ships that throw away more of the valuable fish than the Indigenous fishers are allowed to catch.

img.crdt: Photograph by Danita Delimont, Alamy
img.dsc: Halibut fishing with halibut on the line in Amalik Bay, Alaska.

edgs.abstract: The tiny fishing fleet from St. Paul is losing the fight for halibut, up against factory ships that throw away more of the valuable fish than the Indigenous fishers are allowed to catch.
edgs.title: As halibut decline, Alaska Native fishers square off against industrial fleets

edgs.description: Millions of gallons of wastewater discharged into Tampa Bay may spur red tides or other harmful algae blooms.

img.altText: a reservoir near the old piney point phosphate mine seen from an airplane
img.crdt: Photograph by Tiffany Tompkins, The Bradenton Herald/AP
img.dsc: This aerial photo taken from an airplane shows a reservoir near the old Piney Point phosphate mine, Saturday, April 3, 2021 in Bradenton, Fla. Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency Saturday after a significant leak at a large pond of wastewater threatened to flood roads and burst a system that stores polluted waters. The pond where the leak was discovered is at the old Piney Point phosphate mine, sitting in a stack of phosphogypsum, a waste product from manufacturing fertilizer that is radioactive.

edgs.abstract: Millions of gallons of wastewater discharged into Tampa Bay may spur red tides or other harmful algae blooms.
edgs.title: Hazardous spill in Florida highlights environmental threat decades in the making

edgs.description: Buildings are responsible for a lot of carbon emissions. Weaning them off fossil fuels is a key part of the climate solution.

img.altText: a chef preparing a meal on a gas burner stove
img.crdt: Photograph by Charli Bandit, Getty Images
img.dsc: Chef preparing a healthy dish

edgs.abstract: Buildings are responsible for a lot of carbon emissions. Weaning them off fossil fuels is a key part of the climate solution.
edgs.title: Gas heat and stoves are warming the climate. Should cities start banning them?

edgs.description: Stolen along with the French Crown jewels, this prized blue diamond stayed lost for centuries until the detective work of historians and scientists cracked the case.
edgs.abstract: Stolen along with the French Crown jewels, this prized blue diamond stayed lost for centuries until the detective work of historians and scientists cracked the case.
edgs.title: Stolen in 1792, the French Blue diamond's fate puzzled historians for centuries

edgs.description: The 3,400-year-old royal city was built by Amenhotep III, abandoned by his heretic son, Akhenaten, and contains stunningly preserved remains.

img.altText: Mudbrick walls preserved in Egypt
img.crdt: Courtesy of Zahi Hawass
img.dsc: Mudbrick walls preserved to unusual height and wavy “zig-zag” walls- “The second area which is still partly uncovered, is the administrative and residential district, with larger and well-arranged units. This area is fenced in by a zigzag wall, with only one access point leading to internal corridors and residential areas. The single entrance makes us think it was some sort of security, with the ability to control entry and exit to enclosed areas.”

edgs.abstract: The 3,400-year-old royal city was built by Amenhotep III, abandoned by his heretic son, Akhenaten, and contains stunningly preserved remains.
edgs.title: 'Lost golden city of Luxor' discovered by archaeologists in Egypt

edgs.description: With settlements stretching from Ireland to Turkey, this Iron Age culture used their metalworking skills to build extensive trade networks with ancient Greece and Rome.

img.altText: Four ornate swords
img.crdt: BERTHOLD STEINHILBER/LAIF/CORDON PRESS
img.dsc: These iron and bronze scabbards were found in Switzerland, the product of the Celtic civilization known as La Tène. Emerging in the fifth-century b.c., aspects of the La Tène culture spread to western Europe and are closely associated with modern notions of Celtic patterns and style.

edgs.abstract: With settlements stretching from Ireland to Turkey, this Iron Age culture used their metalworking skills to build extensive trade networks with ancient Greece and Rome.
edgs.title: Who were the Celts?

edgs.description: From their start as “moral homes” to glamorous post-war residences, the hotels offered freedom and community for women redefining America’s idea of their place in society.

img.crdt: Courtesy of Byron Company / Museum of the City of New York
img.dsc: The reception room of the Y.W.C.A/Margaret Louisa Home at 14 East 16th Street, 1907.
img.ttl: Charities, Y.W.C.A. Building, Margaret Louisa Home.

edgs.abstract: From their start as “moral homes” to glamorous post-war residences, the hotels offered freedom and community for women redefining America’s idea of their place in society.
edgs.title: The lost age of women-only hotels

edgs.abstract: A gala parade in Cairo celebrates the golden age of the pharaohs, including one who flew to Paris for a makeover in 1976.

edgs.description: It’s an honor nearly as old as the major league itself—but in 1910, President William Howard Taft transformed the first pitch into the popular ceremony it is today.
edgs.abstract: It’s an honor nearly as old as the major league itself—but in 1910, President William Howard Taft transformed the first pitch into the popular ceremony it is today.
edgs.title: How the first pitch became baseball's Opening Day tradition

edgs.description: Experts are figuring out how to rapidly diagnose and treat the unusual clots linked to both the Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca shots.

img.altText: blood clots
img.crdt: Photograph by Michael Ciaglo, Getty Images
img.dsc: Rocky Mountain Regional VA Medical Center investigational pharmacy technician Sara Berech is reflected in the glass of a fume hood as she prepares a dose of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine for a clinical trial on December 15, 2020 in Aurora, Colorado. The Johnson & Johnson vaccine could be submitted for emergency use by late January and is the only vaccine among leading candidates given as a single dose.

edgs.abstract: Experts are figuring out how to rapidly diagnose and treat the unusual clots linked to both the Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca shots.
edgs.title: What we know about the super-rare blood clots linked to the J&J vaccine

edgs.description: A massive effort to view a black hole in multiple ways is helping scientists untangle what happens when gravity is pushed to extremes.

img.altText: black hole
img.crdt: Image by EHT Collaboration
img.dsc: A view of the M87 supermassive black hole in polarised light: The Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) collaboration, who produced the first ever image of a black hole released in 2019, has today a new view of the massive object at the centre of the Messier 87 (M87) galaxy: how it looks in polarised light. This is the first time astronomers have been able to measure polarisation, a signature of magnetic fields, this close to the edge of a black hole. This image shows the polarised view of the black hole in M87. The lines mark the orientation of polarisation, which is related to the magnetic field around the shadow of the black hole.

edgs.abstract: A massive effort to view a black hole in multiple ways is helping scientists untangle what happens when gravity is pushed to extremes.
edgs.title: New black hole images contain clues to cosmic mysteries

edgs.abstract: New research shows how employers and tech companies can maintain the positive aspects of remote work while reducing the psychological drain, particularly for women.
edgs.title: 'Zoom fatigue' may be with us for years. Here's how we'll cope.

edgs.description: A new study maps out the diversity of our shrieks and wails, raising questions about the evolution of this primal vocalization.

img.crdt: Photograph by Glasshouse Images, Alamy Stock Photo
img.dsc: Humans scream from a wide range of emotions, from anguish to elation. Studying the diversity of our non-verbal vocalizations could help give clues to the origins of speech.

edgs.abstract: A new study maps out the diversity of our shrieks and wails, raising questions about the evolution of this primal vocalization.

img.dsc: Escherichia coli, the yellow rods clustered on a purple substrate.

edgs.abstract: Microbiologists are looking at new ways to fight viral infections, including COVID-19, with the bacteria already living in your intestine.

edgs.description: These are the COVID-19 vaccine prospects that have made it to phase three trials and beyond.

img.altText: woman receives vaccine
img.crdt: Photograph by Frederic J. Brown, AFP via Getty Images
img.dsc: A registered nurse administers the COVID-19 vaccine into the arm of a woman at the Corona High School gymnasium in the Riverside County city of Corona, California on January 15, 2021, a day after California began offering the coronavirus vaccine to residents 65 and older. - US President-elect Joe Biden was set to announce his Covid-19 vaccine rollout plan Friday as he bids to wrest the focus from the impeachment of Donald Trump to the agenda for his first days in office. Biden has said he wants 100 million Americans to receive shots during his first 100 days in office, an ambitious goal that would require a big step up in the current pace of distribution. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP) (Photo by FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images)

edgs.abstract: These are the COVID-19 vaccine prospects that have made it to phase three trials and beyond.
edgs.title: U.S. calls for pause on Johnson & Johnson vaccine after new cases of rare blood clots

edgs.description: Techy apps and paper cards could prove your COVID-19 status, but they might invade your privacy.

img.altText: People lining up before entering a concert venue, many holding their phones
img.crdt: Photograph by Dan Balilty, The New York Times/Redux
img.dsc: FILE -- Music fans show their "Green Pass" before entering a concert in Tel Aviv on March 26, 2021. Vaccine passports are increasingly viewed as the key to unlocking the world after a year of pandemic-induced lockdowns, but they are also stirring complicated political and ethical debates about discrimination, inequality, privacy and fraud. (Dan Balilty/The New York Times)
img.ttl: Music fans show their "Green Pass" before entering a concert in Tel Aviv on March 26, 2021. (Dan Balilty/The New York Times)

edgs.abstract: Techy apps and paper cards could prove your COVID-19 status, but they might invade your privacy.
edgs.title: Challenges surround vaccine passports

edgs.description: As coronavirus forced millions of people around the world into lockdown, another sizeable population had also been hard hit—stray cats and dogs.

img.altText: Woman feeding cats outside
img.crdt: Photograph by Angelos Tzortzini, AFP/Getty Images
img.dsc: Greek volunteer of Nine Lives network Eleni Kefalopoulou feeds cats in Athens on April 8, 2020. - As coronavirus forces millions of people around the world into lockdown, another sizeable population has also been hard hit -- stray animals. While pet owners in many countries are still allowed to walk their dogs, thousands of other animals -- the exact numbers are unknown -- are starving and turning feral. (Photo by ANGELOS TZORTZINIS / AFP) (Photo by ANGELOS TZORTZINIS/AFP via Getty Images)

edgs.abstract: As coronavirus forced millions of people around the world into lockdown, another sizeable population had also been hard hit—stray cats and dogs.
edgs.title: What happens to street animals when tourists suddenly disappear?

cards.description: Scheming invaders. Benevolent vegetarians. Climate refugees. As scientific exploration has advanced, so have creative interpretations of the red planet and its potential residents.

img.dsc: 1939 “The Man From Mars” Drawn by Frank R. Paul for Fantastic Adventures, this Martian is telepathic and can retract his eyes and nose to protect them from freezing.

cards.abstract: Scheming invaders. Benevolent vegetarians. Climate refugees. As scientific exploration has advanced, so have creative interpretations of the red planet and its potential residents.
cards.title: See how people have imagined life on Mars through history

cards.description: Slated to land on Mars this month, the Perseverance rover will search for signs of past life and test new technologies for supporting future human missions.
cards.abstract: Slated to land on Mars this month, the Perseverance rover will search for signs of past life and test new technologies for supporting future human missions.
cards.title: See how NASA’s new Mars rover will explore the red planet

cards.description: The dusty red planet has fascinated us for centuries. Even as we learn more, its mysteries keep us in suspense.

img.altText: blurry photograph of Mars surface with dark spots.
img.crdt: Photograph by E.C. Slipher, LOWELL OBSERVATORY ARCHIVES
img.dsc: Early, blurry views of Mars inspired stories of canal-building aliens.

cards.abstract: The dusty red planet has fascinated us for centuries. Even as we learn more, its mysteries keep us in suspense.
cards.title: Why are people so dang obsessed with Mars?

meta.dsc: A daily peek into National Geographic's vast photography archive.
meta.sclDsc: A daily peek into National Geographic's vast photography archive.

img.altText: Picture of a woman in Saudi Arabia wearing a veil while watching over girls playing on a beach.
img.crdt: Photograph by Jodi Cobb, Nat Geo Image Collection
img.dsc: A story in the October 1987 issue examined the lives of women in Saudi Arabia. Here, a woman wears a traditional niqab, but the young girls won't start wearing the veil until they reach puberty.

caption.credit: Photograph by Jodi Cobb, Nat Geo Image Collection
caption.text: A story in the October 1987 issue examined the lives of women in Saudi Arabia. Here, a woman wears a traditional niqab, but the young girls won't start wearing the veil until they reach puberty.
caption.title: Saudi Women

meta.title: Saudi Women | Nat Geo Photo of the Day
meta.description: A woman wearing a niqab watches over girls playing on a beach in Saudi Arabia in this image from our photography archives.
